@wottle @mike_shay @engadget Here's a fun thing: https://t.co/DQxTTQ3mm6

"The United States spent billions of dollars to curtail the threat of IEDs, but the killing continued long after measures such as radio signal jammers and other equipment saturated the country."
@wottle @mike_shay @engadget Also, the US went to Afghanistan to remove the Taliban. *Literally a trillion dollars later*, who is in charge of Afghanistan? The Taliban.
@GreatPortholio @mike_shay @engadget So you don’t.  But I think we can safely agree that there were no “billions”…

@wottle @mike_shay @engadget If we want to talk about IED attacks in general, though, 81,000 of those took place during the Iraq war, injuring over 21,000 Americans. Which is relevant, because IEDs cost very little, and our military tech doesn't prevent them from working at all.

@GreatPortholio @mike_shay @engadget Do you know how much $1B is?  We lost 80 tanks in Iraq, most due to maintenance issues vs combat.  At $6M each, your numbers seem artificially inflated to prove a biased point.  But I’m sure you have no reason to make up numbers…

@wottle @mike_shay @engadget Well, a quick Google search returns articles from 2011 talking about how a "new" (at the time) truck design could easily cost $600,000. FOR EACH ONE. The US didn't officially get too many of them blown up, but they gave a bunch to the Iraqis, who promptly abandoned them.

@wottle @mike_shay @engadget Do you have any idea how many tens of thousands of dollars we spend flying one drone to deliver one surgical strike to one target, only to miss the target and kill several unrelated people instead, including children?
@GreatPortholio @mike_shay @engadget Gotcha.  I must say I’m glad you aren’t deciding our military budget.  Also, thanks for completely ignoring the fate of Ukrainian in your response.

@wottle @mike_shay @engadget Like, do you know how many billions of dollars we spent on tanks and trucks to send to Iraq, only to have them get blown sky-high by an Iraqi insurgent with a stick of dynamite and a coffee can?
